Today is National School Nurse Day!

You likely know that throughout the school year our nurses support the health needs of our students and advance important health initiatives within their school buildings.

What you may not know is that since the schools closed in March, our hardworking school nurses have been helping the City of Brockton in its extensive contact tracing efforts while also answering calls to the district's Social Emotional Services Call Center.

Today, we thank our school nurses not only for caring for our students but also for supporting for our entire city during this unprecedented time!

March 15, 2020

Dear BPS families,

Earlier tonight, Governor Baker announced a three-week statewide closure of all Massachusetts schools. In light of the Governor's announcement, we are now scheduled to return to school on Tuesday, April 7.

Our food program will continue for as long as schools are closed. Information about that program, as well as learning resources for BPS families, are now available on bpsma.org. We will also have printed learning resources available at all four food program locations later this week.

Governor Baker issued an important reminder that these closures and restrictions on social gatherings are intended to limit in-person interaction. Please support these social distancing measures and, most importantly, please stay healthy and safe.

Thanks,
Superintendent Thomas

This is an important message from Superintendent of Schools Michael Thomas.

At 11:30 this morning, outside grounds keepers alerted Brockton Police and administrators at Brockton Public Schools to the discovery of an unconscious elderly female on the grounds of the Manning Pool located behind Brockton High School. It is believed that she suffered a medical emergency while passing through the area last night.

Brockton Police and State Police responded to the scene and the woman was later declared deceased. Her identity is being withheld out of respect for next of kin.

Because the police investigation was isolated to an area on the edge of school grounds that is not visible to staff or students, the school day at Brockton High was not affected.

On behalf of the entire district, we extend our condolences to the individual's family and loved ones.

The Brockton High School Bilingual Access Center was launched and named today, Oct. 10, 2019, in honor of Jose Pinheiro, Director of Bilingual Education from 2001 to 2014, who began his teaching career in Brockton as its first Bilingual Computer Science Teacher.

The Center is the result of an anonymous $25,000 donation funneled through the Silicon Valley Community Foundation, which provided desktops, laptop cards, smart boards and a wireless display to the smart boards with collaboration tables.

It will be used for support during the day for English learners, writing labs, content/language development and afterschool homework help. It is also a resource for families, and future community meetings can be held there as well.
